question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Keep in mind to do all the homework in advance of class and study the structures daily (you will do because we have daily homework), but always try to listen to the audios that the Instructor records with care for his students, accompanying the vocabulary organizer in Sakai/Canvas, and that will help a lot with your listening skills. The class is extremely organized, and you will thank for that. We have a lot of stuff to do during the semester, but all are very well explained and distributed. Don't feel the pressure to talk the perfect French because it is an elementary level, and M. Choffart knows that! Your speaking is evaluated very fair, with a Boomalang (conversation with a native), but it is just grade on completion, you will not be deducted points for speaking something imprecisely. It is a must take class. Choose French! It was an awesome experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Expect a slightly heavy workload. You definitely have to prepare before each class and spend a lot of time reviewing and studying what you have learned since the material is a lot with a fast course pace. Professor cares more about your participation and engaging with the class, so be ready to talk a lot in the class and get cold-called to say things out loud. Lots of partner work which helps build friendships in the class. He is also a strict grader, so be extra careful about spelling and grammar when turning in checkpoints. But overall, Professor is extremely sweet and makes sure you have a good time. I would absolutely love to have another class with him in the future, he is fantastic.

response_text: Overall, the course had a lot of practice, a lot of intensive textbook work, so it was hard not to learn. The lessons were fairly engaging, a lot of questions responded to and she was very passionate about the course so I enjoyed it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She was very accessible for questions, and very approachable when I had concerns. I loved the grammar homework, as it made sure I was keeping up with the content. I also liked how some homework was participation, as it made it more accessible to complete.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Mme Provot is very well educated on french culture and social and political issues which definitely enhanced the learning environment. For example, when we went to the Nasher or the graffiti museum, she had so much to say and educate us on. The works she selected for us to read, watch, and listen to were very carefully selected as well. Mme Provot has a very clear goal for her class and she knows the means to get there.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As I said above, she made everyone be engaged in class discussions and she always had class organized very well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was very stimulating as there were various elements integrated into class to keep us engaged and active in the discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved the topics discussed in this class, like the French rap and hip hop culture. That was cool and very new for me. I think more little speaking exercises would be nice.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Mme Provot is extremely well-cultured and has taught us much about French culture, which made the class very intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The films and books were very interesting

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A good combination of real-world culture and grammar. Each part contextualizes the other.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There was so much work which forced me to learn the french. The problem with so much work is that it made it difficult to fully engage with everything, and that forced me to put grammar on the back-burner. For a class that is supposed to be the refinement of grammar, I felt that we spent so much time on film and the other works that I wasn't able to develop my actual french grammar nuance how I would have liked. There is so much time to analyze complex aspects of french media and culture in the 300's, so I wish that this class would have been structured in a way that would allow me to give more energy and time to learning French grammar and nuance. I'm not saying to remove the analysis of french works, because I understand this course is preparing us to be able to analyse them, but there are just too many works, and too long of reflections. I understand language takes a lot of work, but this class is extremely stressful to balance within a Duke schedule if you truly engage with all the material; reducing the workload would make students so much happier, engaged, and allow them to learn more.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A lot of work but very rewarding for French growth

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a more complete knowledge of french grammar, I learned how to build upon my french writing skills, and I got to evaluate french media in meaningful and insightful ways.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Improved my speaking and writing skills and understanding of advanced grammar. I believe they can positively one's thinking by broadening their capacity of expression and social understanding. I also learned how to express myself better in writing and use a rich vocabulary.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was always helpful for facilitating class engagement and taking feedback with where we were at as a class. I thought that specifically the film selection was very impressive and thought-provoking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I believe the self-corrections we were able to make were extremely helpful in better understanding our mistakes and efficiently correcting them in the future. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked how prepared Mathilde was each day with slideshow presentations to guide lectures. The class vibe wasn't super formal, but it was really nice to have this source to provide structure and guide us through the lesson. They were formatted very clearly and in a digestible way to take notes, ask questions, and learn. Also, I really liked that we did revisions on our writing based on feedback from Mathilde. I learned so much from seeing where I made mistakes (and what kind of mistakes they were) and having time specifically laid out to work on fixing those mistakes.  Finally, I really liked the selection of films.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: For grammar, the mix of self-corrected textbook work with in class lectures worked well for me. Doing a mix of group and independent work, as well as a mix of writing/art/presentations/verbal assignemnts helped develop differeent facets of language learning for me. Madame Savard-Corbeil created a welcoming environment that made it easy to ask "dumb" questions, and made it clear that her expectation truly was learning, not perfection. She also provides detailed, personalized feedback on most assignments that are clearly meant to help us improve. She makes herself available fopr additional help if needed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think that this is a very engaging class to improve upon previous french skills. I would recommend taking 203 first in order to get a stronger foundation for grammar before, but this is definitely a good continuance.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you dare to pass that limit when it comes to French, take this class, because you feel extremely safe and comfortable to share your thoughts and ideas in French without facing any judgment, your professor will make sure of that. It takes a creative approach to improving your skills in French and you will find joy in learning the language. It won't be something that you just need to do in other to get credit for this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

You will have to do the readings and know the coursework will but will also come away an improved writer and better French learner overall if you do what the course requires of you. It's worth it.

These skills were then applied when answering discussion questions during class allowing me to practice my verbal and listening french skills. Lastly, I learned a lot about French culture involving films, books, plays, etc. Because of this course I was able to be dipped into the world of French culture even further.

Sometimes the discussion topics wouldn't necessarily be related to the book we were reading, but it was nice to just practice speaking french and getting to talk to our peers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the general discussion based classes facilitated my speaking and listening ability in French. I think one of the best things Prof. Rosado did was the extent to which she spoke French. For example, she did not speak French too fast and did not use extremely complex grammar, that way we could understand what she was saying while advancing our skills. She also did a great job at balancing French and English speaking. 90% of the class she spoke French but she understood that there are moments where just speaking in English would enable us to learn more difficult concepts like grammar.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to adapt to an uncomfortable environment and push through in order to make the most of the program. I also realized my ability to put grades aside in order to immerse myself and go to cool places. I didn’t realize before how important it is to stay in french the whole time for improving my language abilities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned French slang and everyday statements that weren’t necessarily in the book. I also learned how to think in French, spontaneously speak in French (both in class and with my host family), and how to use/distinguish between more simple and more advanced French tenses in the same conversation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course - everything from new vocabulary, to grammar, to the tiniest pronunciation details. I wouldn't say I learned, but I strongly developed my ability to correctly conjugate verbs while speaking. In general, I also grew more comfortable speaking in French off the top of my head. By being in Provence, this course made me more aware of cultural differences in France as well

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There were great creative projects that allowed us to apply our vocabulary and grammar. I appreciated the excursions that immersed ourselves in the french culture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that Madame Provot cold called on people sometimes. The daily homework was essential to knowing what would be talked about in class the next day, even though it was a lot sometimes. I also liked the Warpwire audio for the vocabulary, which helped me improve my speaking a lot. The in-class partner activities were also fun because we got to practice the grammar out loud versus just reading and/or memorizing the spellings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: They were engaging in class most of the time and encouraged us to engage and participate outside of class. However, the environment created was not a good one. I always felt pressured to participate and act like a "perfect" french student because I thought my participation grade would drop if I did not. I would keep the structure of the class, but the general environment needs to change for the sake of students' mental health. I think everyone agreed that we felt like we could not approach them with issues regarding workload or mental health because they made it seem like we were supposed to know that this course is intensive and "what we signed up for."

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that by relating the course content to our activities, they helped us learn in a less formalized manner, which I enjoyed. The grammar lessons in class always were, for the most part, always interesting, especially when we could collaborate with peers. I think that overall the class content was taught very well, in a way we were able to learn a lot in a very short period of time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The creative activities were helpful but I would appreciate more creative assignments instead of the workbook homework.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked the use of multimedia in-class, and the different projects about Aixoise culture. I felt that Provot’s lessons were more fast-paced than Howell’s, but they were both intellectually stimulating as Howell’s lessons typically required more deep thinking and elaboration, versus Provot’s lessons required more engagement and paying attention to keep up.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating and I did improve upon my french skills. I think it could be more stimulating if the class was more varied and the excursions were things that students would actually want to do (for example, kayaking/caves/light show were the best activities, but we went on too many history tours).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made it stimulating was the way they related the course content to our activities along with all the excursion we would do. The class was very stimulating, if not too stimulating that it was just exhausting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is difficult but extremely rewarding if you put in the needed amount of effort from day one.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared for insane rigor, more than you’d expect. It’s worth it but you will be exhausted by the end.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will get out of it what you put into it. It’s easy to complain but the point of the program is to immerse, so it will be fast-paced and there will be a lot of work. However, it’s literally the point of the course so you can’t be too mad at it. It’s how you learn.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to work a lot and not have much free time/alone time. If you are a person that gets tired from being with others and needs relaxation, I do not recommend this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is exhausting. I am so grateful that I took the opportunity and came here and I am happy to have had the experience, but I felt exhausted most days. The homework takes at least 2 hours every night and the day-long excursions can be tiring. You need to have a good work ethic in order to succeed.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: When they say it's intensive- they truly mean it. However, my french did improve a lot and I had some incredible experiences during our excursions both in and outside of Aix. If you're truly interested in learning French it's worth it, but if you're trying to have a relaxing time in the south of France you won't get that.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: They were engaging in class most of the time and encouraged us to engage and participate outside of class. However, the environment created was not a good one. I always felt pressured to participate and act like a "perfect" french student because I thought my participation grade would drop if I did not. I would keep the structure of the class, but the general environment needs to change for the sake of students' mental health. I think everyone agreed that we felt like we could not approach them with issues regarding workload or mental health because they made it seem like we were supposed to know that this course is intensive and "what we signed up for."

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I gained an in-depth understanding of the political and governmental structure in France. Prior to this course, I didn't really have much, if any at all, understanding of governmental systems and structures, and this course allowed me to gain an understanding of not only the French government but also the US government as a result of comparing the two. 
2) I gained an understanding of the core values that pervade how French politics are shaped and how French citizens respond to issues. 
3) I learned to identify certain political biases in news platforms and articles and how different each political party address the same issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned SO much about French society in this course! I learned about the historical context of why the French think the way they do (i.e. common good as opposed to individual liberties); how French politics work (governmental structures, what the prominent political parties's values are, and prominent political figures); and how the French healthcare, education, and social handouts systems work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Take this course!!!! Especially take this course if you're thinking about studying abroad, travelling or working in France! It is SO helpful to better understanding how French society works and how French people think, and you learn SO much about current events. I did a summer internship in France a couple years before I took this class, and I so wish I had been able to take this course before my internship, because I think it would have helped me better adapt to the culture and the country, and better understand some of the cultural differences that I encountered that aren't obvious.
As a side note, I happened to take this class at the same time as I was taking AAAS 380: France and Africa, taught by Stephen Smith, and these two classes complemented each other SUPER well--I would definitely recommend the combination.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about current events in France, including the environmental transition there and the state of their education and healthcare system. I also learned a lot about the historical and philosophical underpinning of its government, and what makes French citizens more likely to support a socialist/redistributive system. I also have a good understanding now of the social aid systems that French citizens can take advantage of, as well as the integration, immigration, religious, and national debt challenges facing French society. It is very interesting to see the way French society operates in comparison to US society. There are many different cultural aspects and underlying assumptions that I would never have imagined.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I feel like my understanding of France as a nation and people has greatly improved after taking this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The two oral exams at the end of the course were a great way to push students to develop their oral skills throughout the semester and I found it quite stimulating to present a topic of interest in the French news. I am also extremely grateful for Dr. Gonthier because she is always open to meeting with her students and helping them navigate the course topics or just discussing various other topics. She is extremely flexible and her seminars are extremely encouraging and spark fruitful debates between students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the discussion based class is helpful, and I enjoyed speaking in the smaller groups. I enjoyed the interactive activities in class, like the crosswords and exercises on paper. I believe more of those would help keep class time dynamic and engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was very close and conversational. We covered a lot of material in class, which allowed us to learn a lot about politics and life in France. I particularly enjoyed the debate assessment, where we had to discuss a complicated issue with another member of the class, as it gave us an opportunity to revisit much of the material from the class while simultaneously keeping the nuance of what we had read in mind.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new information about energy and carbon usage in France as well as more about how they play a grand role in the world of green policy reform and innovation. I also really loved learning about climate issues in French colonies which I felt did a lot of justice to more diverse perspectives in the francophone world. Oh also so much about environmental impacts on viticulture in France and the fallout around the world!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot more about conversational French and was able to speak more freely without penalization, which helped me to grow my skills. I also learned about wine growing in france and how that impacts the climate, which I really enjoyed. I also learned to read through more advanced texts, like a graphic novel about chlordecone in the antilles, which was challenging but rewarding.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. History vs. history 
- I didn't understand a lot of the brutalities that happened during Colonial France, especially from the authentic perspective of the victims. It was interesting to see how these histories were different from the surface-level textbook history that is more commonly taught. Prof taught us the significance between History vs history. One being the overarching conventional history, while the other documents everyday life for those who are not involved in surface level history, which probably affected more people. This was something that I referenced throughout this course as well as other courses. 
2.  Drawing Parallel
- Prof pointed out lots of parallels throughout the books we studied. How different subjects in the book act as metaphors for other things. 
3. Philosophy
- prof drew ideas from philosophers that supplemented the course

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) General content/knowledge - the overarching topic that we explored throughout this course is one that I hadn't ever really had exposure to. From something as simple as making the distinction between "réfugié(e)" to "demandeur d'asile" at the beginning of the course to now being able to formulate literary and experiential analyses on different genres of works, I have gained the knowledge and more in-depth understanding of the refugee crises and experiences in different time periods as well as different parts of the world. 
2) Ways of thinking - This course has allowed me to exercise critical and evaluative thinking by considering different perspectives towards similar events portrayed by different works and different artists or authors and how the differences can affect the way the audience perceives a given experience. 
3) Skills (language) - my general level of the French language has certainly also improved since I was encouraged to speak in class, which improved my French speaking skills, and there are many writing practices and that enhanced my French writing level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Reisinger's class stood out for its engaging and collaborative environment. She encouraged us to lead the discussions, which shifted the dynamic from a traditional lecture to a more interactive and communal learning experience. This approach not only deepened our understanding but also fostered a sense of camaraderie among us.The respectful debates and discussions we had in class were a highlight. It's a testament to Professor Reisinger's skill that, despite differing opinions, everyone maintained a great deal of respect for each other and for her. Her kindness and thoughtfulness in guiding these discussions were truly appreciated.Additionally, the diverse range of readings she selected were thought-provoking and contributed significantly to the richness of our discussions. This style of teaching, where students feel like active participants in a learning community, was both refreshing and effective. I believe it's a method that would be beneficial in future courses.

response_text: I think that the instructor and my peers have created an environment that allowed me to more comfortably speak in a language that I definitely didn't feel confident in using at the beginning of the course. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made Professor Reisinger's class particularly stimulating was the way she framed the course with nuanced questions that encouraged deep thinking and analysis. These questions weren't just academic; they challenged us to consider broader perspectives and underlying themes in our studies.Another aspect that greatly contributed to the intellectual stimulation of the class was the context provided for each piece of material we consumed. Understanding the background and nuances of each work enriched our discussions and allowed us to engage with the content on a much deeper level.Moreover, the diversity of our course materials (in terms of periods, places, mediums, and content) was remarkable. From readings to assigned films, each piece was carefully chosen to complement and underscore the message that the migrant experience is far from singular. This variety not only kept the course dynamic and interesting but also broadened our understanding of the subject matter in a way that a more uniform set of materials could not.In short, the course was intellectually stimulating as it was. The diverse materials, along with Professor Reisinger's thought-provoking questions and insightful context, created a rich, multifaceted learning experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was much more work than I thought it should have been, and I felt sometimes that students were graded unfairly. Students who routinely came into class 30 minutes late were never penalized, but students at a higher level of French (or honestly just engagement) were held to a higher standard and punished for failing to meet it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are considering this course, I highly recommend it, particularly for its incredible service learning component. This course is more than an academic endeavor; it offers a unique opportunity to extend your learning beyond Duke and meaningfully engage with the Durham community. The volunteer experience is integral to the course and significantly enhances its value.Through this service learning aspect, you will engage in activities that are much larger than yourself. It is an opportunity to apply classroom knowledge to real-world situations, making a tangible impact in the community. This experience not only deepens your understanding of the course content but also imparts important life lessons in empathy, responsibility, and community involvement.Additionally, this course provides a deeper understanding of Durham's dynamics, allowing you to form connections and gain insights into the community in ways that might not have been previously apparent. It is an enlightening experience that broadens your perspective and fosters a sense of belonging to something greater than the university environment.Therefore, if you are prepared for a course that challenges you academically while offering meaningful community engagement, this course is an excellent choice. You will gain not just knowledge, but also invaluable experiences and connections.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about the different conflicts in the context of the French Opera, Ballet, and Theatre which helped me understand the existence of these institutions in modern-day France as well as how and why they mattered to the shifting power structures in the region in the last few centuries. I have been able to develop more nuanced analytical thinking skills in the realm of French history which, in turn, has deepened my appreciation for the main figures associated with that history.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say this is an incredible course to take if you are interested in social issues of race, femininity, and sexuality in the context of French culture and through the lens of film. I think Dr. Joseph-Gabriel is an incredible instructor, and should truly be more popular at Duke than she is (I think it is just because she is new). This course will be intellectually stimulating and challenging but it won't feel as though you are fighting an uphill battle grade-wise. Dr. Joseph-Gabriel is very fair via grades and cares much more about your learning than your letter grade. As long as you engage daily with the course material and show that you care, you will succeed and take so much from this course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor and TA really helped us by guiding our readings with complementary texts that we used as tools to better understand the books. I liked that we always discussed these texts in class, and everyone could add their own ideas, which made the discussions richer and helped with critical thinking, especially with literature. Their guidance was very important because the books we studied were new and there weren’t many resources online. Also, the open discussions encouraged everyone to speak, which helped us see different perspectives. As the representative delegate, I could also see that our guidance was much stronger compared to other universities, where students sometimes showed a more superficial understanding, probably because the material wasn't always structured (in a class) and taught by a professor, like it is at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell a student to take this class if they have a genuine interest in literature and truly enjoy reading. It’s a very complete class because you learn literary concepts that improve your critical thinking, and you also get exposed to important cultural and social phenomena happening in France. I would also say that you need to feel confident with your french skills, because the class requires a good level of understanding and speaking. At the same time, it’s a great way to improve your speaking, because you have to express complex ideas in a very supportive learning environment. But most importantly, genuine interest is key. Since the class isn’t required, having real motivation will make the experience very enjoyable.
